DataElement.preferredName: Serum Biclonal Gammopathy Immunoglobulin Heavy Chain Present Specify Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The free-text field to describe biclonal immunoglobulin heavy chain(s) in the serum.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Serum Biclonal Gammopathy Immunoglobulin Heavy Chain Present
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed._A primary disturbance in immunoglobulin synthesis characterized by the presence of two distinct monoclonal immunoglobulins in the serum or urine._A protein complex that consists of two heavy chains (gamma, alpha, delta, epsilon or mu). The larger of the two immunoglobulin chain types determines the immunoglobulin class (G, A, D, E or M, respectively). The heavy chain molecules exhibit the same structure and composition, which consists of constant, variable, and hypervariable regions._Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Serum Biclonal Gammopathy Immunoglobulin Heavy Chain
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.:A primary disturbance in immunoglobulin synthesis characterized by the presence of two distinct monoclonal immunoglobulins in the serum or urine.:A protein complex that consists of two heavy chains (gamma, alpha, delta, epsilon or mu). The larger of the two immunoglobulin chain types determines the immunoglobulin class (G, A, D, E or M, respectively). The heavy chain molecules exhibit the same structure and composition, which consists of constant, variable, and hypervariable regions.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
A primary disturbance in immunoglobulin synthesis characterized by the presence of two distinct monoclonal immunoglobulins in the serum or urine.

A protein complex that consists of two heavy chains (gamma, alpha, delta, epsilon or mu). The larger of the two immunoglobulin chain types determines the immunoglobulin class (G, A, D, E or M, respectively). The heavy chain molecules exhibit the same structure and composition, which consists of constant, variable, and hypervariable regions.

Property.preferredDefinition: Being or existing in a specified place or at the specified time.
